final_answer.precision_note: Answer is given to 3 significant figures, matching the concentration of NaOH (0.150 mol dm-3).

method: First, the volumes are converted from cm3 to dm3. The moles of NaOH (n_B) are calculated using the concentration formula n = c * V: $n_{NaOH} = 0.150 \text{ mol dm}^{-3} \times (23.40/1000) \text{ dm}^3 = 0.00351 \text{ mol}$. Next, the moles of H2SO4 (n_A) are found using the stoichiometric ratio from the balanced equation (L40), which is 1:2 (H2SO4:NaOH). $n_{H2SO4} = 0.00351 \text{ mol} / 2 = 0.001755 \text{ mol}$. Finally, the concentration of H2SO4 (c_A) is calculated using $c = n/V$: $c_{H2SO4} = 0.001755 \text{ mol} / (25.00/1000) \text{ dm}^3 = 0.0702 \text{ mol dm}^{-3}$.
checks: All volumes are converted to dm3 for the molarity calculation.
The 1:2 mole ratio from the balanced equation is correctly applied.
The final concentration (0.0702 mol dm-3) is reasonable for a titration.
